channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Trump’s New National Security Strategy Goes Full ‘America First’
item.description: The long-anticipated plan aims to selectively impose the U.S. president’s worldview around the globe.

item.title: Xi, Macron Seize Symbolic Victories in Unorthodox Summit
item.description: Both China and France hope to strengthen their images on the world stage amid growing isolationism.

item.title: Biden’s Long Shadow Over Ukraine
item.description: His administration failed Ukraine at almost every turn, shaping the war to this day.

item.title: When the Democratic Recession Comes Home
item.description: Michael McFaul wants more democracy promotion. Is now the time?

item.title: A Kaleidoscopic Portrait of Women in Taiwan
item.description: “Left-Handed Girl,” Taiwan’s Oscar hopeful, offers a multifaceted view of women learning to live beyond shame.

item.title: A Jekyll and Hyde for the Manosphere Crowd
item.description: “The Things You Kill” explores the pitfalls of masculinity in modern-day Turkey.

item.title: Two Unsettling Voyages Across the Sea
item.description: Plus, more international fiction releases in December.

item.title: What in the World?
item.description: Test yourself on the week of Nov. 29: A disease outbreak ends in Congo, Trump pardons a former Honduran president, and the latest from Israel-Palestine.

item.title: Does Europe Finally Realize It’s Alone?
item.description: Washington’s new National Security Strategy ratifies an adversarial relationship.

item.title: Britain’s Fiscal Watchdog Doesn't See What Matters
item.description: By ignoring the long-run effects of both government-funded and privately funded innovation, Britain's official budget scorer has been systematically underestimating the economy's potential output and the government's future fiscal headroom. The result is not fiscal discipline, but a costly illusion.

item.title: The Critical-Minerals Race Is Putting the Planet at Risk
item.description: As governments weaken environmental protections to promote new mining projects, the global scramble for critical minerals is deepening social divides and harming vital ecosystems. Only reduced consumption and robust, enforceable rules can prevent long-term harm and protect basic human rights.

item.title: The Transformative Power of Early Childhood Education
item.description: In a world marked by volatility, no investment yields greater economic returns than supporting children in their first five or six years of life. Yet pre-primary education remains chronically underfunded, blocking the surest route to a more prosperous, peaceful, and stable world.

item.title: How China Now Talks About NATO and Why It Matters for the Asia-Pacific
item.description: Until 2021, statements about NATO in Chinese foreign and defense ministry press conferences were few and largely neutral in tone. Then the tone hardened.

item.title: Hybridization of the Terror Threat in India
item.description: Recent incidents point to the use of advanced operational techniques and technologies, signaling an increasing hybridization of terrorist techniques, tactics, and procedures.

item.title: What Does China Want? Depends Which China You’re Talking About.
item.description: China gives conflicting signals because it has three different “personas”: Moral China, Defensive-Assertive China, and Striving China.

item.title: India and the Gulf States Could Reshape Global Trade
item.description: In an increasingly multipolar world, India and the Gulf states are no longer merely trading partners but strategic actors in their own right. Together, they are advancing a model of cooperation that values autonomy, transparency, and mutual gain over coercion and dependence on great powers.

item.title: Trump Has Many Options if the Supreme Court Strikes Down Tariffs
item.description: A weak Congress means a deep toolbox for the president.

item.title: Former Japanese PM Ishiba Shigeru Has Thoughts on His Successor
item.description: Ishiba has critiqued current Prime Minister Takaichi for her Taiwan remarks, nuclear policy, and rice vouchers.

item.title: Why hangovers get worse as you get older
item.description: But there are things you can do to help

item.title: A Forgotten Hostage Crisis: Bangladeshi Citizens in the Arakan Army’s Captivity
item.description: Far away from the scrutiny of the international community, the Arakan Army is holding hundreds of Bangladeshi citizens as hostages.

item.title: Europe’s Tech Firms Need Regulation to Grow
item.description: The European Commission's rushed plan to water down landmark dig’ital legislation reflects the view that excessive regulation is to blame for the lack of European firms capable of competing with the US tech giants. This logic is fundamentally flawed, and deregulation is destined to backfire.

item.title: The $500 Mistake: Why International Students in Australia Are Selling Their Bank Accounts to Criminals
item.description: That “easy money” comes with a steep cost: a criminal record, a lifetime ban from Australia, and up to life imprisonment.

item.title: Hong Kong’s Grenfell Tower Moment: When Grief Became Sedition
item.description: As families sift through ashes and survivors call for accountability following a catastrophic building fire in Hong Kong, authorities have moved swiftly to silence dissent.

item.title: China and India’s National Strategy and Competition in Cislunar Space
item.description: The paths of China and India in space show how Asian space powers are fundamentally transforming the global distribution of capabilities and influence in cislunar space.

item.title: ASEAN Between China and the US: Navigating a ‘No Single Power’ Global Order
item.description: Economic strategy can no longer be separated from geopolitics. How, then, should ASEAN position itself?

item.title: Want an Explanation for China’s Nuclear Build-up?
item.description: It’s not in the new white paper.

item.title: From Theft to Labubu: The Evolution of Intellectual Property Protection in China
item.description: After decades of accusations over counterfeiting foreign brands, Chinese companies are now assuming dual roles: as not only IP violators, but also IP proprietors.

item.title: Why China Can’t Make Gwadar Work – Even After Billions Spent
item.description: Gwadar port has often been touted as CPEC’s “crown jewel.” Yet almost two decades after the port began operations, business has been lackluster.

item.title: Donald Trump’s bleak vision of America’s foreign-policy priorities
item.description: Allies may panic; despots will cheer

item.title: Donald Trump’s bleak, incoherent foreign-policy strategy
item.description: Allies may panic; despots will cheer

item.title: Trump Is Threatening His Own World Cup
item.description: Ongoing immigration raids risk the success of the global sporting event.

item.title: Trump’s Authoritarian Innovations
item.description: During his second presidency, Donald Trump has joined a long line of autocrats who come to power through elections only to erode democracy, with the ultimate goal of installing an authoritarian regime. But much about his first year back in office more closely resembles the aftermath of coups.

item.title: Thailand Girds For Early 2026 Polls Amid Economic Stagnation
item.description: Months of political instability expected to ensue

item.title: An AI Bust May Not Be All Bad News
item.description: The boom makes it hard for competitors to step away from a treadmill of continuous acceleration.

item.title: The End of the Israel Exception
item.description: A new paradigm for American policy.

item.title: What Syrians Want
item.description: A new survey shows the promises and perils facing the country’s new government.

item.title: For Rohingya Women in Bangladesh, Digital Freedom Is a Distant Ideal
item.description: Life in the heaving camps around Cox's Bazar is marked by a daily struggle for even basic connectivity and safety.

item.title: Malaysia’s Rare Earth Transition
item.description: An early adopter hopes to make “super magnets” for electric cars by 2030.

item.title: Singaporean Court Upholds Opposition Leader’s Conviction for Lying to Parliament
item.description: Pritam Singh of the Workers' Party told the press that he was "disappointed" with the decision but accepted it "fully and without reservation."

item.title: Landlocked Africa is an open opportunity for Australia
item.description: Rather than compete on aid volumes, Australia could leverage remote logistics expertise as quality partner for major projects.
